Name: Jar
Description: Vessel of Egyptian alabaster, with two perforated handles, flat base, convex profile, wider at the out-turned rim, partly lost. This stone jar was found in a tomb at Tarkhan, a rich cemetery from the time of the first recorded unification of Egypt, around 3000 BC. The grave measured 28 by 55 by 60 inches, containing a contracted body, with head to the south, and face turned facing west. The other grave goods included a siltstone cosmetic palette, for grinding eyepaint, some malachite, a green copper ore used for eyepaint, and an armlet and beads.
